body.p: With great interest, we read the article by Lindroos et al.1 wherein the clinically relevant topic of a combined crystalloid and colloid fluid concept is investigated, with regard to the influence of the solvent solution on coagulation in vitro. A balanced and unbalanced 6% hydroxy-ethyl starch (HES) 130/0.4, and an unbalanced 4% gelatin solution were combined with either a balanced or unbalanced Ringer’s solution. The authors concluded that a combination of balanced colloid and crystalloid solutions had similar effects on coagulation in vitro as the respective combination of unbalanced solutions. Our concern with that conclusion is the choice of the “unbalanced” crystalloid solution, as the chosen one is a Ringer’s acetate solution containing sodium, chloride, potassium, calcium, magnesium, and acetate1.

A commonly accepted definition of an electrolyte-balanced solution is an electrolyte composition close to that of human plasma2-4. Thus, balanced solutions usually contain fewer sodium and chloride ions than saline, but more cations like potassium, magnesium, and calcium, and degradable anions such as acetate, malate, or lactate2.

In our opinion, the chosen “unbalanced” Ringer’s acetate is, in fact, a balanced solution, therefore, not a single one of the investigated crystalloid/colloid combinations is a truly unbalanced one. The conclusion that a totally balanced volume replacement therapy is lacking additional advantages regarding coagulopathy is, in our view, not supported by the presented data. This is the reason why this issue remains unresolved and requires further investigation. Apart from this, there are at least two more reasons why these studies on the effects of balanced versus unbalanced colloid solutions are important: 1. These solutions are widely used in hospitals worldwide; 2. Due to the widespread use, the results of research on the safety of colloid solutions may directly affect and improve patient safety.
